*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 149593 ***

bug.short_desc: MessageFormat problems

long_desc.thetext:
If a Feature Label View Pattern has illegal format, MessageFormat construction throws an IllegalArgumentException (e.g. #1 rather than 1# in a choice). This is not caught and the attempt to register the EditPartProvider fails leaving the editor very dead. The message could be validated during diagram generation, and the exception tolerated at run-time.
If a Feature Label View Pattern uses a boolean feature for a choice, ChoiceFormat throws an IllegalArgumentException which is not caught by the generated getStringByPattern. This has similar bad consequences.
Since ChoiceFormat is broken for booleans, and since choices are a far from Turing-complete computation mechanism, an ability to define an OCL expression to prepare each View Pattern argument would be helpful.

bug.short_desc: DocumentProvider.computeModificationStamp fails for plugin resources

long_desc.thetext: Attempting to initialise an ecore_diagram for a model that references Ecore results in an NPE at the file.getLocation.toFilelastModified() of EcoreDocumentProvider.computeModificationStamp since a plug-in resource such as L/org.eclipse.emf.ecore/model/Ecore.ecore returns null as its location.

Workaround:
Import org.eclipse.emf.ecore into the workspace, so that the resource variant is available to provide a timestamp.

Can not reproduce this situation in my workspace. Nevertheless, found a stupid error in DocumentProvider.computeModificationStamp() method. Error corrected. Please, check latest build from 2.0 branch and reopen request if problem is still there.

The converse of the workaround in #2 is that the bug is only reproducible if your workspace does not have org.eclipse.emf.ecore loaded as a project.
It should reproduce because plugin models have no location.
Yes, exactly.

bug.short_desc: JEM isn't visible as an installable component

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Try to install a plug-in 2. Have the updater tell you that this requires JEM 3. Search in vain for anything called JEM in the eclipse list of downloads by project or by topic.
More information: This won't be obvious to anyone that's associated with Eclipse because they know what JEM is, but it took me ten minutes of hunting to decide that it looked like part of the VE project.
It would be fine for this to be hidden information if it wasn't for the fact that JEM is listed as a dependency by other updates and, in my case, by the PHPIDE project.
My suggestion is that the downloads page adds some form of index of eclipse acronyms so that people can work out what something like JEM or (for another example of something I had to hunt down) WTP is part of. With WTP I got lucky because it's a project rather than a component of a project so it's listed in the Download 'topics' page. SDO was another fun one to find. You're developing a really bad case of the 'inventing our own secret language' problem that can block access to your product by new users. Of course I've been using Eclipse for two years and still have problems working out how to update stuff so maybe it's just a case of nobody wanting to work on the install and update issues.

Each project has its own download page, so I will move this to the PHP project download page where you said you encountered the problem. That page should tell you exactly what the prerequisites are and how to get them.

can you clearify what exactly the bug is?
I know that we had some work on dependencies alert, and it is not closed yet.
This bug isn't relevant, since WST is not dependent on JEM anymore (beginning from 2.0)
closing this bug, see latest comment by spektom

bug.short_desc: wrong quoting of identifiers

long_desc.thetext: Sorry, two mistakes: Of course, i was talking about DatabaseMetaData.getIdentifierQuoteString() and DatabaseMetaData.getCatalogSeperator() instead of Connection.getIdentifierQuoteString() and Connection.getCatalogSeperaot().

Hey Hung,
I think this is a problem in org.eclipse.datatools.sqltools.data.core. I've attached a patch which should address the issue.
Thanks, Rob
Created an attachment (id=61433) Patch
Behaviour has not changed in 1.5M6
Applied Rob's patch. Thanks!

I'd like to know, if the current logic takes care of the fact, that JDBC does not supply a strategy for escaping the quoting-character if it's part of an identifier.
For example:
quoting char is ", table name is foo"bar quoting char is ', table name is foo'bar
In that case, the routing doing the quoting should maybe throw an exception rather than generating illegal identifiers like "foo"bar" or actually applying any default strategy.

OK, i'll answer myself:
DTP applys a default strategy. The result of foo"bar will be "foo""bar", for example.
I don't know if this is a good idea, but it's what my database expects. So i won't complain.

bug.short_desc: Leading space in extenpoint schema editor

long_desc.thetext:
3.3 M4
Please see the attached screenshot. Each wrapped line starts with a space. That's kind of weird. Usually the space is appended to the line before.
Created an attachment (id=56272) Screenshot of schema editor

Using valuable input from Brian and Daniel Megert, I investigated into whether PDE needed to create a custom IDocumentAdapter instead of using the DefaultDocumentAdapter created by TextViewer in order to handle wrapping properly in a JFace SourceViewer.
Two solutions are apparent:
(1) Insert custom newlines between lines based on the present Control width (2) Partition the document lines based on the present Control width (much like ConsoleDocumentAdapter)
Neither of these solutions feel right. It seems like specifying the SWT.WRAP style on a SourceViewer should be sufficient without having to do any extra work behind the scenes. SourceViewer creates StyledText under the covers using the style.
From my investigation, the unwrapped line is passed in as is to StyledTextRenderer.
Transferring to SWT for their input and further investigation.
Changing the Product/Component to SWT.
A wrap bug?

Mike & Brian: Is there special character embedded in the text ?
If you say that passing the string as is to the StyledText triggers the problem then it would be easy for you to write a snippet to help me reproduce the problem in my machine. Thanks.

I have to refresh my memory on this bug and re-investigate. As far as I can recall there was no special character embedded, just the extra space. I'll see what I can do with respect to the snippet as time permits

Do you guys still have this problem. Note: I don't see this problem in any of my testcases. So please provide a testcase that I can use to reproduce the problem in my machine or close this problem report if the problem is gone for you.
closing as works for me. Please reopen if this is still a issue for you.

bug.short_desc: Drag and Drop copy within GMFgraph editor creates wrong node

long_desc.thetext:
2.0M3 Using DND within the GMFGraph editor to drag a "Diagram Label":
<labels name="UMLXClassVariableName" figure="UMLXClassVariableNameFigure"/>
onto its parent "Canvas" which normally creates a copy, does indeed create another "Diagram Label" but its actually:
<nodes xsi:type="gmfgraph:DiagramLabel" name="UMLXClassVariableName" figure="UMLXClassVariableNameFigure" elementIcon="false"/>

Looks like a problem in EMF-generated code.. DiagramLabel extends Node, so it will be added into the incorrect containing feature - "nodes" instead of "labels" on d&d.
If we will change gmfgraph meta-model to not extend Node by DiagramLabel this will probably fix the situation.
Generated CanvasItemProvider was modified to handle this situation correctly.

bug.short_desc: Multiple Feature Label Mappings per Node Mapping do not work

long_desc.thetext: 2.0M3 If a Node Mapping has two Feature Label Mappings, only the first is processed to resolve its View Pattern, the second retains its default text.

The problem arose from upgrading: original diagram had a single Feature Label mapping. GMFmap then upgraded to two mappings. Old diagram edited with new editor does not fully pick up the extra Feature Label mapping and so only maintains the first. Elements created post upgrade maintain both.
So the bug/feature? is the failure to adjust read-in diagram elements to the prevailing diagram behaviour.

Well, to me it's just not reasonable to check every existing view element read from xx_diagram file whether it conforms to existing ViewFactory implementation (which is responsible for adding e.g. child label views).

bug.short_desc: @OrderBy not implemented yet

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: I have annotated a One-to-Many association with @OrderBy on the many side like this but the mapping for this is not produced:
<eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="instruments" upperBound="-1" eType="#//pareis/trading/Instrument" containment="true" eOpposite="#//pareis/trading/Instrument/Client"> <eAnnotations source="teneo.jpa"> <details key="value" value="@OneToMany(indexed=false) @OrderBy("id")"/> </eAnnotations> </eStructuralFeatures>
More information:

Is solved in cvs. Will be in the next release (this week). Note that the orderby annotation should contain the column name and not the property name. This differs from the ejb3 spec which allows the property name, the hibernate mapping xml requires the column name however.
gr. Martin

bug.short_desc: ECJ -J option should be implemented

long_desc.thetext:
The -J option of the eclipse java compiler is currently reported as being ignored, and likely is. Because of this, ecj may fail with the large projects like GNU Classpath when the compiler runs out of the allowed memory. With the recent GNU Classpath CVS head, the following message was observed:
/usr/bin/ecj -1.5 -J-Xmx400m -warn:-deprecation,serial,typeHiding,unchecked,unused,varargsCast -proceedOnError -bootclasspath '' -classpath ../vm/reference:..:../external/w3c_dom:../external/sax:../external/relaxngDatatype:../external/jsr166:.:: -d . @classes incorrect classpath: Exception in thread "main" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space
When using Sun's javac, the -J-Xmx400m options helps to pass this place of compilation, asking to give more memory. Without this option, javac fails exactly with the same out of memory error and on the same build line as well.
Reported against Eclipse Java Compiler v_585_R31x, 3.1.2 release under Fedora Linux (i686 architecture)
Can we do something here, since we are not building the executable ourselves.

The trivial workaround is to find the ecj startup scrip (this may be the /bin/ecj or something like that) and manually edit it how needed (the script contains the commands to launch the eclipse with the default java virtual machine).
The real solution would be to provide a startup loader that would check the options, needed to pass to the virtual machine, and would pass them. This likely should be written in C.
Closing as INVALID. We don't build the executable or provide the script. This should be done when building the executable or inside the script.

bug.short_desc: Resolution of unresolved or partly resolved BillOfMaterials

long_desc.thetext: The resolution currently starts with a CQuery and results in a BillOfMaterials. We must also be able to deal with partly resolved BillOfMaterials that can be passed between different RMAP providers.

The resolution process was cleaned up and some interim nodes were removed in the UI graph in favor of BOM's. We now have a better separation and a resolver that always creates BOM's. It can now also start with an unfinished BOM.
The Resolver constructor no longer relies on that the CQUERY contains an RMAP URL. This URL can be passed in separately.
Released with 1.0.0.v20070108

bug.short_desc: [Navigator] error markers do not show properly in navigator view

long_desc.thetext:
This bug is just like bug https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=147467
Bug 147467 fixed the problem happens in "Project Explore" view,but the error markers are still not showing properly in "Navigator" view.
1. launch eclipse3.2.1,create a java project and a class 2. Window --> Show View --> Navigator 3. type some error code in the new class (e.g. bad imports,wrong types and so on),save and build the project,notice that the error markers do not show properly in "Navigator" view.
What is thought as fixed for bug 147467 is the "Project Explore" in J2EE perspective,yes,in 3.2 version,error markers even not show properly in "Project Explore",and they show exactly with 3.2.1 version.However,seems you guys forget the "Navigator" view...
I even test using a clear eclipse SDK 3.2.1 (without any other plugins),the error markers show in "Package Explore" view and "Project Explore" view,but just do not show properly in "Navigator" view.
The error markers are not decorators.

This is working as designed. The Resource Navigator does not show error markers. It never has and, now that the Project Explorer is the main Resources view, we do not intend on adding any new features to the Resource Navigator.

bug.short_desc: A problem of the borders on table detail row in PDF [0300]

long_desc.thetext:

bug.short_desc: EMF allows creating a derived attribute object and shows it in the tree

long_desc.thetext:
I have a derived attribute called parent to keep the containment of an object. I use an OCL expression to set its value when an object with this attribute is created as shown below.
<eClassifiers xsi:type="ecore:EClass" name="Library" eSuperTypes="#//Base"> <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="name" eType="ecore:EDataType http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore#//EString"/> <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="books" upperBound="-1" eType="#//Book" containment="true"/> </eClassifiers>
<eClassifiers xsi:type="ecore:EClass" name="Book" eSuperTypes="#//Base"> <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="parent" eType="#//Library" changeable="false" volatile="true" transient="true" derived="true" containment="true" resolveProxies="false"> <eAnnotations source="http://www.eclipse.org/OCL/examples/ocl"> <details key="derive" value="Library.allInstances()->any(books->includes(self))"/> </eAnnotations> </eStructuralFeatures> </eClassifiers>
After generating code for my model, I ran it. When I instantiate Book in the above example as a child of a Library instance, I get the parent instance set as expected. But the "Create Child" contextual submenu of a Book instance contains an item to create parent, this time grayed out. And the "parent" attribute set using the OCL expression is shown in the EMF tree as a child to the Book instance. This means that tree elements are shown repetitively (indefinitely). That is visually difficualt to work with. It is better to have an instance only once in the tree or atleast to not show derived attributes which are defined types.
I added one more hierarchy as follows
<eClassifiers xsi:type="ecore:EClass" name="School" eSuperTypes="#//Base"> <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="name" eType="ecore:EDataType http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore#//EString"/> <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="libraries" upperBound="-1" eType="#//Library" containment="true"/> </eClassifiers>
After generating the code, I started running with Book as a root. In the "Create Child" contextual submenu of this root instance "Parent Library" was shown in as an item without being grayed out. The created Library instance lands no where.
below is my complete ecore model for reference.
Thanks, kibebew

The "parent" property in the quoted Ecore model is specified as a containment reference:
<eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="parent" eType="#//Library" changeable="false" volatile="true" transient="true" derived="true" containment="true" resolveProxies="false"> ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
This is what causes the generated editor to show the parent as a child node and to include a "Create Parent" action in the menu.
This reference could be marked as a *container* reference by specifying Library.books as its eOpposite, but in this case the OCL derivation is unnecessary as EMF already knows how to derive container references from the eContainer pointer.

Yes, that is true. But it is inconvenient to see a single object many times on the tree and to have derived attributes in the "Create Child" list.
(In reply to comment #1) > The "parent" property in the quoted Ecore model is specified as a containment > reference: > <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EReference" name="parent" > eType="#//Library" > changeable="false" volatile="true" transient="true" derived="true" > containment="true" resolveProxies="false"> > ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ > This is what causes the generated editor to show the parent as a child node and > to include a "Create Parent" action in the menu. > This reference could be marked as a *container* reference by specifying > Library.books as its eOpposite, but in this case the OCL derivation is > unnecessary as EMF already knows how to derive container references from the > eContainer pointer.

Marking an EReference as "isContainment" in the Ecore model when it is, in fact, intended to be a non-containment reference is simply a modeling error. I don't see why it would be inconvenient that the generated editor treats it as a containment when it is specifically told to do so.
OTOH, I'm not sure whether EMF intends to support derived containment references (in which case there would not be a Create Child menu action). I don't think it makes sense, as containment is generally persisted, so that it wouldn't actually be derived. In any case, this question is for EMF codegen and is unrelated to OCL.

Thank you. You pointed me to what I forgot to mention. I set the containment of my derived attributes in Rational Rose to "By Reference" in the "Detail" tab of their specification dialogs. How ever, the contaiment is always set to true in the corresponding ECore models. I set the containments to false by hand in the ECore model have noticed no change regarding the problems I reported. Coming to persistence, the derived attributes are not persisted regardless of whether I set their containments to true or false.
(In reply to comment #3) > Marking an EReference as "isContainment" in the Ecore model when it is, in > fact, intended to be a non-containment reference is simply a modeling error. > I don't see why it would be inconvenient that the generated editor treats it as > a containment when it is specifically told to do so. > OTOH, I'm not sure whether EMF intends to support derived containment > references (in which case there would not be a Create Child menu action). I > don't think it makes sense, as containment is generally persisted, so that it > wouldn't actually be derived. In any case, this question is for EMF codegen > and is unrelated to OCL.

Ecore has no analog for by-reference aggregation in UML. Such an association simply maps to a non-containment reference. So, I'm already a bit suspicious when you say that it's still mapping to containment.
Christian's comment is totally correct. You shouldn't be using OCL for what you're trying to do. You should just make the association bidirectional: the two references will be created as opposites of each other, and everything will just work.
Note that if you change your model source and "reload", the Ecore model be rebuilt, but the settings on your GenModel decorators will be maintained. So, if you've changed containment references to non-containment, you may still end up with containment-like behaviour. The simplest fix is to delete your .genmodel file and create it from scratch.
I'm seeing a misunderstanding, but not a real problem, so I'll mark this bug INVALID. If you'd like to continue to discuss the issue, please do so in the newsgroup. If you can demonstrate a problem, please reopen the bug.

I know it is possible to do what I did using bi-directional references. I have a request to do the way I did it. It was preferred to not see back references in the UML model. It is atleast uneasthetic. I did it this way intentionally, not because of misunderstanding.

Clearly, we have very different aesthetic senses. For me, the simplest model that does what I want has strong aesthetic appeal. :)
Also, if you're not actually interested in surfacing this reverse relationship in the model, but only want access to the parent programmatically, there's an even simpler option: just don't model it at all. Every modeled object already makes its container available via EObject.eContainer().
In any case, apologies for not being clear in my previous comment: I believe that what you're trying to do is already possible. But, as Christian said, marking your Book.parent reference containment was a mistake for at least two reasons: (1) a containment reference should not be derived, and (2) circular containment is not allowed, that is, an object may not contain its own container.
To test, I took the Ecore model you attached, removed all the scope references (since they're not relevant to this problem), and for each parent reference, changed containment to false.
I created a GenModel and noted the following relevant default properties for each parent reference:
Children: false Create Child: false Notify: false Property Type: Readonly
As I said in my previous comment, these would be different if you created the GenModel when the reference was containment. Even if you changed the reference to be containment and reloaded the model, you would still need either to set them back to these values or simply to delete and recreate the .genmodel file.
I then generated code. Because I don't have OCL installed right now, I just replaced the default, exception-throwing implementation of the getParent() methods by a simple implementation like this (in BookImpl, for instance):
public Library getParent() { return (Library)eContainer(); }
If the OCL interpreter can return the same thing based on an expression, that should make no difference.
When I ran the editor, it worked exactly as expected. The parent reference is realized as a non-editable property showing the school or library that contains the selected library, book, or writer. There are no extraneous children or "New Child" menu items present.
Since I've got a working test case, I'm marking this bug WORKSFORME.

...aesthetics, I agree with you. The reason I didn't want to rely on EObject.eContainer() is to make the UML model even language independent. I want to do every thing regarding modelling at the UML model (Rose model for me) level. With the settings you described and setting containment=false by hand (because attributes I set as referenced in Rational Rose have been imported as contained). I got the result I wanted to have. I used my OCL expressions as they are. Using Eclipse as a black box is not yet ok because I have to make the settings I described. I think I can open a new branch for that. I set this bug as closed.
(In reply to comment #7) > Clearly, we have very different aesthetic senses. For me, the simplest model > that does what I want has strong aesthetic appeal. :) > Also, if you're not actually interested in surfacing this reverse relationship > in the model, but only want access to the parent programmatically, there's an > even simpler option: just don't model it at all. Every modeled object already > makes its container available via EObject.eContainer(). > In any case, apologies for not being clear in my previous comment: I believe > that what you're trying to do is already possible. But, as Christian said, > marking your Book.parent reference containment was a mistake for at least two > reasons: (1) a containment reference should not be derived, and (2) circular > containment is not allowed, that is, an object may not contain its own > container. > To test, I took the Ecore model you attached, removed all the scope references > (since they're not relevant to this problem), and for each parent reference, > changed containment to false. > I created a GenModel and noted the following relevant default properties for > each parent reference: > Children: false > Create Child: false > Notify: false > Property Type: Readonly > As I said in my previous comment, these would be different if you created the > GenModel when the reference was containment. Even if you changed the reference > to be containment and reloaded the model, you would still need either to set > them back to these values or simply to delete and recreate the .genmodel file. > I then generated code. Because I don't have OCL installed right now, I just > replaced the default, exception-throwing implementation of the getParent() > methods by a simple implementation like this (in BookImpl, for instance): > public Library getParent() > { > return (Library)eContainer(); > } > If the OCL interpreter can return the same thing based on an expression, that > should make no difference. > When I ran the editor, it worked exactly as expected. The parent reference is > realized as a non-editable property showing the school or library that contains > the selected library, book, or writer. There are no extraneous children or "New > Child" menu items present. > Since I've got a working test case, I'm marking this bug WORKSFORME.

You shouldn't have to set your references to non-containment manually. Maybe there's an issue in your model, or perhaps a problem in RoseEcoreBuilder? If you could send me a small sample model, I could investigate further.

Created an attachment (id=56702) Rational Rose (V 8.5) file containing derived attributes contained by reference
Here is the Rose file I produced the ECore file you already saw from.

Created an attachment (id=56703) Rational Rose (V 8.5) file containing derived attributes contained by reference
Here is the Rose file I produced the ECore file you already saw from.

Created an attachment (id=56704) Rational Rose (V 8.5) file containing derived attributes contained by reference
Here is the Rose file I produced the ECore file you already saw from.
Attached is the Rational Rose file I derived the ECore model from. Sorry for the repeated attachment.

You should model parent (and scope) using associations, not as attributes.
EMF maps UML associations to Ecore references, and UML attributes to Ecore attributes. In Ecore, an attribute may only have a data type as its type, and reference may only have a class as its type. When RoseEcoreBuilder sees that you have attributes with class types, it converts them to references, but it always considers them containment references, since the whole-part relationship in containment is more analogous to that of an attribute.

We are getting back to my original claim. Who wants to see back references for all containment references in a complex model? You can look at scope as a root container. Imagine how your UML model would look like if you build references to it all over. That is actually the reason for me to use derived attributes. I think RoseEcoreBuilder has to translate the model 1:1. If Rose model marks an attribute as "contained by reference" so should the Ecore model. The same thing holds if the containment is by value. It should make a decision if the model sets containment to "Unspecified".
I think RoseEcoreBuilder can do what it does for reference association to resolve this.

Aha! It's all clear now!
I wasn't even aware that Rose had a containment option for attributes, which probably led to me not really understanding what you were getting at before.
It's true, we were never considering the containment setting for attributes that we convert to references. And we certainly could. I'll attach a patch with the change.
Assuming no one's unhappy with this patch, I'll commit it in time for next week's build.
That said, I don't agree that modeling references as associations necessarily leads to ugly, unreadable models. We've never had a problem doing so. In your example, couldn't you have modeled scope directly on Base? Then you would've just had one short reference from Base to itself? Also, if you'd used bidirectional associations, instead of a separate parent reference, that wouldn't have added any more lines.
In general, if a model has too many lines on it to reasonably lay out, that's usually an indication that you've included too many different concerns in one diagram. The solution is to split the model up into multiple diagrams.
Created an attachment (id=56851) Proposed patch to RoseEcoreBuilder.java

I agree it is possible to take relations up to the base class unless one wants to do class specific stuff. If RoseEcoreBuilder is fixed this way, we only remain with the .genmodel settings you mentioned, i.e. Children: false Create Child: false Notify: false Property Type: Readonly if they are not derived from the containment type. I'll download the update when it is available and test. I hope it'll appear in the Linux version too.

The fix is in CVS.
It will be in our build this week. We only have a single, platform-agnostic build, so you should be able to test on the platform of your choice.
Reopening to test fix for bug 171745.
Marking assigned to test fix for bug 171745.

bug.short_desc: JET should commit workspace changes within an appropriately scoped scheduling rule

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, when JET commits workspace changes, it uses IWorkspace.run(IWorkspaceRunnable, IProgressMonitor). This results in the most conservative IScheduleRule implementation, the workspace root.
This is problematic when a JET Transformation is run within another IWorkspaceRunnable that specifies a scheduling rule. In this case, the JET invoked workspace operation fails with a message such as:
Attempted to beginRule: R/, does not match outer scope rule: MultiRule[...]
JET has the information necessary to construct an appropriately scoped scheduling rule. It should do this.
Changing to an enhancement.

bug.short_desc: Editor components for editing IP-XACT files (contribution)

long_desc.thetext: DSDP have agreed to use IP-XACT (from The SPIRIT Consortium) as the basis for debugger target descriptions. To assist in this process ARM have created some IP-XACT editor components which we would like to contribute to Eclipse. This Bugzilla entry will be used to contribute these components.

Created an attachment (id=56282) core plugin for editing of IP-XACT files
This plugin contains code that understands and handles the objects represented by IP-XACT documents. It also contains code for the handling of libraries of IP-XACT documents. The file is a jar file including the source code of the plugin.
The plug-in is currently named com.arm.ipxact.editor.core, but will need to be renamed for inclusion in Eclipse.
All code in this plug-in is either written by ARM Ltd. from scratch, or derived by ARM Ltd. from existing Eclipse code (licensed to ARM Ltd under the terms of the Eclipse Public License). ARM Ltd. offers use of this code to the Eclipse Foundation for its use under the terms of the Eclipse Public License.
The code contains no cryptography code.

Created an attachment (id=56283) ui plugin for editing of IP-XACT files
This plugin contains code that: - Extends the Web tools XML editor to provide specific support of IP-XACT - Provides additional views for the support of IP-XACT libraries. - Provides IP-XACT specific drag and drop functionality between these views and the editor views. - Provides an IP-XACT Perspective - Provides a wizard for the creation of new IP-XACT files.
The plug-in is currently named com.arm.ipxact.editor.core, but will need to be renamed for inclusion in Eclipse.
All code in this plug-in, with the exception of AutoResizeTableLayout.java, is either written by ARM Ltd. from scratch, or derived by ARM Ltd. from existing Eclipse code (licensed to ARM Ltd under the terms of the Eclipse Public License). ARM Ltd. offers use of this code to the Eclipse Foundation for its use under the terms of the Eclipse Public License.
Details of AutoResizeTableLayout.java's derivation and licensing follow in the next comment.
The code contains no cryptography code.

Created an attachment (id=56285) Permission to contribute AutoResizeTableLayout.java
The code of AutoResizeTableLayout.java (included in the editor UI plug-in) was originally copied from a book. The attached email gives us permission to use this code in any manner whatsoever. On this basis, we (ARM Ltd.) are contributing it to the Eclipse Foundation under the Eclipse Public License.

(In reply to comment #2) > > The plug-in is currently named com.arm.ipxact.editor.core, but will need to be > renamed for inclusion in Eclipse. > This plug-in is actually named com.arm.ipxact.editor.ui.

and

bug.short_desc: [Launcher] Eclipse won't launch in Mac OS X 10.5

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2
Steps To Reproduce: Note: You need to be a ADC Select or Premier member to reproduce this.
1. Install a developer seed of Mac OS X 10.5 (9A321 is the latest developer seed) 2. Launch Eclipse 3.2 or later
Result: an alert appears indicating that Java failed with exit 1.
More information: This is happening because the platform launcher code is checking whether or not argv[1] begins with "-psn_". Changes in application launching in 10.5 removed this argument, and as a result the application doesn't check for the correct startup parameters in its Info.plist file. Startup.jar can't be found, so Eclipse fails to launch.
The existence of the '-psn_' argument is an undocumented implementation detail, and shouldn't be relied upon.

As it turns out, it's not even necessary to make this check. Eclipse will launch correctly from the command line or as a bundled application without it. It's sufficient to check for the existence of the main bundle, and then look inside the Info.plist. A patch is coming shortly.

Created an attachment (id=56284) Patch for bug
Sorry for the somewhat excessive diff. I removed an if test so the indent level changed.
I also verified that this works in both 10.4 and 10.5 (and probably back to 10.3.9, though I didn't try it.)
Is this something we should fix in 3.2.2 as well?
Yes, if you can. I'm assuming Leopard will be released before 3.3 goes final.

Fixed > 20070105.
Released the changed C code and the recompiled launcher into HEAD for 3.3.
Fixed also in new equinox launcher (equinox-incubator/org.eclipse.equinox.executable). Recompiled and released to HEAD.
Thanks, everyone! I will notify the appropriate people here.
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: [API] Expose a means to programmatically set and load a Target Platform

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061214-1445
Currently there is no means to programmatically load or set a Target Platform. To load or select a Target Platform a user must open the Preferences dialog and manually select the platform that will be loaded.
The classes for loading a Target Platform are all internal and even the constants for setting the Target Platform preferences are in an internal class.
A means to programmatically select a Target Platform based on either a *.target file or a specified directory should be exposed. At the bare minimum the constants for setting the Target Platform preferences should be moved out of the internal package.
This might be one we can use in making PDE more of a platform.

We also have a need to be able to build tooling, on top of PDE, that is able to get and set the runtime target platform.
The use case for this is that we would like to create tooling for commercial OSGi-based servers, where the tooling is specific to and dependent upon this runtime's application development environment (i.e. it's own set of APIs, services, extension points, etc).
To provide such tooling, and make it usable, it would be necessary to be able to get/set/manipulate the target platform from within our tool plugins.

bug.short_desc: Errors when using classes from sun.misc

long_desc.thetext:
For some reason Eclipse 3.3M4 now produce access restriction errors when attempting to use sun.misc.Signal and other related classes in similar packages in the rt.jar. This is unfortunate since it's the only mechanism available for installing things that can trap for instance a CTRL-C in a headless command-line framework.
Where are the access rules for the rt.jar defined? Who decides what should be restricted and what not?
Move to JDT/Debug

When a project's build path is bound to an "execution environment", such as J2SE4, access rules are added to the build path to reflect what is present in that environment at runtime (based on OSGi profiles). If you want to access sun.misc classes, etc., then you should put a specific JRE on your build path rather than an execution environment.

I'd like to use J9, JRockit, Sun, GCJ (and all others that use the GNU Classpath). AFAIK all of them implement the sun.misc package. Most people that build the bundle in question will only have one of them installed. So how would putting 'a' specific JRE on my build path help with this particular problem?
When you add a specific JRE to the build path there are no access rules added. The access rules come with execution environments. See bug 163444.
My point is that I have no specific JRE to add. If I add a specific JRE, I limit myself to that particular JRE. I don't want to do that since most JRE's (all that I know of) implement this package.

CC'ing Wassim & Tom for comment. I believe you can add an access rule on the "execution environment container" to get around this problem - i.e. add an access rule that provides access to all packages.

(In reply to comment #5) > My point is that I have no specific JRE to add. If I add a specific JRE, I > limit myself to that particular JRE. I don't want to do that since most JRE's > (all that I know of) implement this package.
Do you specify a Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment header? If so what value do you use? J2SE and JSE execution environments do NOT define the sun.misc package as part of the API. That package is not part of the Java specification. When you use the Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment header PDE attempts to resolve the JRE classpath container to a compatible JRE that implements the execution environment you specified (you have to click the "Update the classpath and the compiler compliance settings" link on the manifest overview tab to do this).
This will cause the access rules from the specified execution environment to be applied to the JRE classpath container. This list of access rules will not contain sun.misc because that package is not part of the Java specification.

Yes, I'm using the J2SE-1.4 execution environment. The reason I'm using this is that I want to make sure that: a) Continued development of the bundle stays within what a normal JRE 1.4 can handle. b) I want the bundle disabled if its execution environment is incompatible.
I can understand and appreciate that the execution environment is constrained to what's defined in the Java specification. Using them seemed like a good idea in Eclipse 3.2 since it did not enforce this. Now I have the situation where I want to enforce a) and b) above and at the same time allow use of sun.misc which I know that most JRE's indeed do implement. So what's the best course of action for me? Can I state an execution environment with exceptions?

Wassim or Darin will have to answer this one, but I think there is a way to change the errors to warnings for the JRE access rules on a per project basis. Maybe you can change this to a warning only for your project that uses sun.misc.

bug.short_desc: Generic API for detecting sync actions.

long_desc.thetext:
This functionality is needed for Eclipse Corona project. We need to have an ability to detect that a certain action (commit, update) was invoked on CVS/Subversion/etc. (SCM).
The Eclipse Corona project is a collaboration tool for Eclipse. One of the core elements are events propagated within a project team. The events contain notification about changes in resources. So, for instance we send an event that someone is editing a file. If an other user edits the same file, he might be notified about potential conflict, before something is committed to SCM. Users may prevent the conflict.
An ability to detect sync events is crucial for us: 1. inform others about events in SCM; for instance users are definitely interested that something was checked in 2. we need to somehow distinguish a resource change event caused by SCM update operation
Ad. 1. We need to detect what SCM action was perform, when it was started and finished, what was the result of the action (success / failure).
We have developed something for CVS only, using CVS internal packages. It is based on console listener. It might be broken easily if something is changed in CVS implementation. We would also need to implement something similar for every single SCM (Subversion, MS VSS, ..), which probably is even impossible. For this reason we need it in generic API.
Ad. 2. Note that SCM update causes a resource change event. We think that a user has changed the file, so we send event to the team members that the user is working on that file. So the team members are mislead, because they think that some conflicts may appear, while the user in fact got synced. Instead of thinking everybody are synchronized, team is informed that everybody are getting more and more out of sync.
We have already if this functionality is provided: http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/platform-team-dev/msg00238.html

Once you start talking about collaboration tools, I think you really need server support but what you are asking for is support on the client. For instance, if perform a check-in and my Eclipse crashes after the check-in but before Corona processes the event, then the other users will never be notified of the event. Another failure case, is the case where a user is using another client to perform the check-in. In this case, no notification would occur. It is far better to implement this type of notification on the server. CVS has support for running scripts in response to commits and I assume Subversion has similar capabilities.

But the server side solves only a part of the problem (use case 1.). But we still do not have an ability to distinguish if local files were modified by user or were they changed by update or commit (commit may change keywords) (use case 2.).

Additionally putting it server side isn't a generic approach. - What if I do not have administration permissions to SCM server (eg. CVS at eclipse.org)? - What if a SCM doesn't support scripts? - It makes us again implement it for every single SCM. So, we would need one for CVS and Subversion, etc.

In regards to comment 3, your points are valid. That does not mean that we should have support for this in Platform/Team. I should think that the best way to start would be to define the API you need and provide implementations for a reasonable subset of repositories (e.g. CVS and Subversion). As your project matures, users of other repositories may be motivated to provide additional bindings. If, at some point, the API has a wider applicability than just the Corona project, it could be moved to a more general project such as the Platform. This is the approach taken by Mylar for their repository integration.
In regards to comment 2, from your original description it sounds like you only need this when sending notifications from the client to other users. If the capability was provided by the server, you would not need to distinguish user changes from updates. As for user edit notification, this is supported by many repositories. For CVS, this capability is provided using the Watch/Edit support.

More input on comment 2.
We want to inform the team that someone is working a given file, before it is commited to CVS. This may help people if for instance two are working on the same file and they don't know about it. With Corona they will be notified about it.
To do this, we use resource change events sent by workbench. The problem is that when a user synchronizes his/her project with SCM, the same kind of workbench event is sent. So, when someone makes an update, we detect change of a file and broadcast information to others. So others thinks that the user has modified his copy while he only did an update.

I understand. What I am saying is that there is already a mechanism in most repositories for this. For instance, CVS has Watch/Edit which can be configured to send notifications when files are being edited and also when files are checked in or the local changes thrown away.

bug.short_desc: Service oriented data management infrastructure

long_desc.thetext:
This feature should provide a service oriented data management infrastructure.
This feature should also be the answer to scalability related requests.
The infrastructure could be based on a two layer design where the top layer provides the data domain abstractions and the lower layer represents the data store abstractions. The application code is supposed to interact only with the top layer where the top layer will transparently interact with the lower layer.
The main capabilities of this infrastructure should be:
- allow high performance read/write and analysis of large data sets (limited by the disk availability). - provide a simple data representation as the default implementation (should cover the current analysis, viewing, and reporting operations for most data domains, initially it may not support completely the complex filtering found in some existing scenarios) - provide support for extensibility for both data domain level and data store level interactions - allow any concrete data store to participate in the data persistence layer (should not be limited to RDB concrete implementations) - should also work on a single machine with embedded data stores (also allow disconnected mode)
This is intended to replace the current EMF based implementation, basically to achieve a simple and more scalable view of the data operated by the TPTP UI, analysis and reporting components.
The event processing (data normalization) will be covered in the component that covers load data operations (basically the event loaders will interact with this component).
Gradually we will move TPTP functions to use this infrastructure (as this will become concrete), backward compatibility should be maintained.
*** Bug 116098 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Design work has started in mid December.
Marius: Please open a stage 2 enh to track all work items outside of the scope of TPTP 4.4. This stage 2 enh will be targeted to 4.5. (future for now)

This enhancement covered the initial work on a new DMS API, API used in Cosmos EclipseCon 2007 demo, plus model related work to enable the Test model to work with database resources.
The remaining work (outside of 4.4 scope) would be handled in bug 185783.
We will continue to investigate and materialize the statement of this feature (mentioned in the description) as part of bug 185783.

bug.short_desc: Debug Variables View temp. shows blank lines when Show Constants is off.

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061214-1445
I have a class that implements an interface that defines many constants. When I expand an instance of this class in the Debug Variables view when "Show Constants" is off, I get many blank lines for a while before they are removed. It's as if there is a blank line for each constant. The blank lines are removed only once all the constants have been "identified". With many constants, this takes a while.
This was confusing to me for a while since I didn't realize that if I waited for 30 seconds, the view would return normal.
I've attached a test case that includes an interface defining 500 constants.
More information:

Created an attachment (id=56294) Test case - main class
This is the main class for the test case. Put a breakpoint on the return in main() to reproduce the problem.

Created an attachment (id=56295) Test case - TestConstants interface
This is the large interface of constants.

Created an attachment (id=56296) Screen shot
Screen shot of the Variables view with the blank lines.

Created an attachment (id=56297) Test case - TestConstants interface
This is the interface that defines a bunch of constants. This version removes the bogus copyright boilerplate.

This is due to the "virtual" implementation in the debug views. We only retrieve/display variables that are visible in the view so filtering is performed dynamically as variables are retrieved. Thus, the variables appear and then disappear as they get filtered. Most times this is not noticeable as only a few variables are filtered.
Nothing planned for 3.3

Same problem here (debugging Apache Batik). Quite an annoying thing. I'd love to see this improved.
Looks like someone else has the same problem, too: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=195400#c11

Created an attachment (id=84677) patch
Work in progress to continue in M5. Moves filtering support into the JDT debug model and content provider.

bug.short_desc: Help for Loading EMF Documents is Incorrect and not Formatted Correctly

Steps To Reproduce: To reproduce:
1. Open Help>Contents 2. Open EMFT JET Developer Guide 3. Open Tasks 4. Open topic names "Using JET Transformations with EMF Documents"
More information: The help content for the task "Using JET Transformations with EMF Documents" has lots of formatting mistakes (wrong escapes). More important, the "Loading EMF Documents" section names the wrong ID for the ModelLoader extension point. It says "org.eclipse.jet.xml" instead of "org.eclipse.jet.emf". Unfortunately, that's probably the most significant piece of information in this topic.

This has been fixed in JET 0.7.2, which will be released in sync with the February Callisto maintenance release and Eclipse 3.2.2.

bug.short_desc: When ManagedService.updated() throws an unchecked exception, the update thread dies

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Write a ManagedService that throws a NullPointerException from its updated() method 2. Try to modify its configuration through the org.eclipse.equinox.cm bundle. This will trigger the NullPointerException 3. Note that the thread performing updates to ManagedServices has died and will no longer update ManagedServices
More information: The problem is in the implementation of the method asyncUpdated(ManagedService, Dictionary) of class org.eclipse.equinox.cm.internal.ConfigurationAdminFactory$ManagedServiceTracker.
Whenever a ManagedService must be updated, this method schedules a Runnable to perform the update with a queue. This (anonymous) Runnable does catch ConfigurationExceptions, but it does not catch unchecked exceptions. As the bundle is calling into another bundle, it's reasonable to catch any Exception or even Throwable here, especially because failing to do so causes the entire CM implementation to stop working.

Agreed. Now that you mention it, this highlights other similar problems as we also need to catch all exceptions for ManagedServiceFactory updates and deletes as well as ConfigurationPlugin configurationEvents.
I'll add a patch to this bug shortly and then we should look to test and move it into the depot.

Created an attachment (id=56301) patch to catch exceptions
This is an initial patch to catch the exceptions as per this bug report and the CM spec for: 1) ManagedService.updated 2) ManagedServiceFactory.updated and ManagedServiceFactory.deleted 3) ConfigurationListener.configurationEvent
J. could you try this patch out. Thanks.
I'll do some testing and assuming all goes well move it into the depot.
I've tested and committed this patch to HEAD. If you're still having problems please re-open this bug.
Will this be going into 3.2.2?

Hi Bruce,
The Config Admin implementation is currently in the graduation process and awaiting final reveiw, stamp of approval etc. See bug 162773. I suspect it will be formally available in 3.3.
That said, the implementation can (and is) being used in 3.2 and what's more is supported.

bug.short_desc: [key binding] Ctrl+O during code assist disables key bindings

Build ID: I20060810-1230
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Open some existing Java file in a Java editor, and trigger an autocomplete popup, for example, by typing "return get", and pressing CTRL-SPACE, to see a list of getters. 2. While the pop-up is still being displayed, press CTRL-O to attempt to open the quick-outline. The quick-outline does not actually show up. 3. Dismiss the autocomplete popup by clicking somewhere else. 4. Try the shortcuts CTRL-O for quickoutline, CTRL-SHIFT-F to format the code, etc. They will no longer work. 5. Close and reopen the Java file (doesn't matter whether you save the changes). The shortcut keys CTRL-O and CTRL-SHIFT-F will work again.
More information:
This is broken since day one except that in 3.0 and earlier you have to give the focus to the completion proposal window (e.g. by pressing Tab).
Fixed in HEAD. Available in build > N20070103-0010.

bug.short_desc: Eclipse3.3M4 w/ IBM JDK doesn't respect -Xmx flag

long_desc.thetext:
1. 'Window > Preferences... > General > [x] Show heap status'
2a. Launched like this:
/home/nickb/eclipse/eclipse/eclipse \ -vm /opt/sun-jdk1.5.0_09/bin/java \ -data /home/nickb/eclipse/workspace \ -Xms128M -Xmx256M
I get Eclipse 3.3M4 w/ a varying heap status tooltip reading:
Heap size: 177M of total: 217M max: 247M mark: <none>
2b. But, launched like this:
/home/nickb/eclipse/eclipse/eclipse \ -vm /opt/ibm-java2-sdk-50-linux-i386-20060511sr2/bin/java \ -data /home/nickb/eclipse/workspace \ -Xms128M -Xmx256M
I get Eclipse 3.3M4 w/ a varying heap status of:
Heap size: 177M of total: 217M max: 2023M mark: <none>
Is this a JDK bug? Or a problem with the way the eclipse executable handles commandline flags like -Xms and -Xmx?

You seem to be missing the -vmargs argument. Every argument after -vmargs is passed to the JVM, and all other arguments are assumed to be arguments to Eclipse/OSGi. Try this:
/home/nickb/eclipse/eclipse/eclipse \ -vm /opt/sun-jdk1.5.0_09/bin/java \ -data /home/nickb/eclipse/workspace \ -vmargs -Xms128M -Xmx256M

So I guess that makes this a WONTFIX / PEBCAK bug, eh? ;-) Why does Eclipse + the Sun JDK respect the flags w/o the -vmargs flag butwhen using the IBM one they're ignored? Or is it ignored in both cases but Sun is less grabby with max memory allocation default?
Only arguments after -vmargs are sent to the VM, so you must have been getting the default setting on those VMs.

2.0M3+ the Dashboard greying out policy is not as clear as it could be, in particular there is an ambiguity between greyed-out-because-not-available and greyed-out-because-already-done.
Ambiguity is increased by the failure of the 'lite' items to greyout, so the commonest problem after allowing the project selection to drift, is to see a grey 'generate diagram' but a blue 'generate 'lite' diagram'. They are blue initially because they are defined in other plugin and I use proxies to prevent it's activation when actions are shown; it's activated only when actions are invoked and after that they are grey if not enough info is specified in dashboard.

bug.short_desc: Improved property testers

long_desc.thetext:
Two changes should be made: * The server-type property tester should handle ModuleServer objects as well.
* A new module-type property tester should allow enablement expressions based on module-type, and preferably module-version as well.
Created an attachment (id=56303) Potential patch

I was able to give this a try in my development workspace for a popup menu command to clean the server work directory for a module and it worked successfully.
Though I wouldn't normally use moduleVersion, I tested this as well. If checking single versions, the user may need to remember to enclose the value within single quotes to avoid having the specified value boxed. For example, testing for "jst.web" and version "2.4", one would need to specify the value as "'2.4'". Using "2.4" would cause the expected value to be boxed into a Float and the matching would fail.
It might be worth considering passing in "expectedValue.toString()" instead of null if expectedValue isn't already a String. For many "normal" uses, the test would still work even when boxing is occurring. Only if the value is boxed and the specified string doesn't roundtrip, such as for "001" or ".10", would the developer trip over this issue. This might not be that much harder for the developer to figure out than if all boxing causes the test to return false.
Changes released to 2.0 M5 builds.
Verified, closing.

Sorry, was cleaning up bugs and didn't see your previous comment. I think we should open up another bug to make access to ModuleServer public, whether it be through making that class or an interface public, or the changes you suggest above. Do you want to open it or shall I?

bug.short_desc: Add or fix translation directives in .properties files

long_desc.thetext:
The IBM translation process requires comments in the .properties files to act as directives for translation. In particular
# NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_ALL All values in this properties file will be processed by MessageFormat. Apostrophes must be doubled in every message in which they are used.
# NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_NONE No values in this properties file will be processed by MessageFormat. Apostrophes must be coded exactly as wanted.
# NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_VAR Only values in this properties file that have substituted text (for example, {0}) will be processed by MessageFormat. For those values, apostrophes must be doubled.
Also # NLS_ENCODING=UTF-8 should be specified for all properties files since it is not assumed.
All .properties files that are used as resource bundles have been examined and fixed if necessary.
verified by running chkpii on properties files captured on 2007-02-06

bug.short_desc: Deprecated Information

long_desc.thetext:
Manifest Headers that are deprecated like Export-Service / Provide-Package should have information why they were deprecated and what are appropriate paths of change. In the past, when I came across a deprecated header, I would just see the information in the hover that it was deprecated since version whatever, however, there was never a reason why / migration story included in the hover description.
What are people's thoughts about including this information?
since PDE extracts the javadoc from the osgi plug-in to display it in the hover, this enhancement belongs in that bucket.

Wassim, what javadoc do you use to display deprecation information in the manifest editor? We do not ship any javadoc from the org.osgi packages. instead we just link to the online javadoc available from osgi.org site.

btw, I noticed there's no hover for Provide-Package that would imply there's no doc for it. Want a separate bug for this Tom? I figure if there's doc on Export-Service there should be info on Provide-Package.
I don't understand where you get the hover information from for Export-Package. There is no public java api to stick javadoc for Provide-Package.
from the Javadoc of org.osgi.framework.Constants

We will have to figure out another way to get deprecated information on the Provide-Package header. The org.osgi.framework.Constants class never has had a constant for Provide-Package header. And we do not want to add a constant to any class just to deprecate the constant.
not much can be done at the tooling level then.

bug.short_desc: Downloads link points to empty dir; downloads path is non consistent w/ other projects

long_desc.thetext:
http://download.eclipse.org/tools/orbit is an empty dir. The real contents are in http://download.eclipse.org/tools/orbit/committers/drops/I200612120722/, for example. Why is this path introducing a new path convention? For consistency w/ other projects, why not use /tools/orbit/downloads/drops/<version>/<buildID> ?
Also, I notice there's an updateSite/ folder within the build's folder; can I assume this is temporary and will eventually be centralized into something like /tools/orbit/updates/ ?
Cheers,
Nick

Hi, Nick,
I don't think I can comment on the download directory name (I assume it's just a test build, since we haven't any news that Bjorn and David have completed the build system).
However, regarding the update site: Orbit actually does not plan to publish an update site at all. Orbit bundles will be delivered via their client projects' features on their update sites.

I'm not sure when this was open, relative to the builds and their writeup, but think most of this is explained in
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Orbit_Builds
But to emphasize some points,
1. There is no "version" of Orbit planned. Since the third party code we are bundling has already been released elsewhere, we'll simply declared "bundle ready for adopter consumption" at some point.
2. The "committers" area is for "initial builds" of the bundles. Once we believe them suitable for adopter consumption, we would move them to the "downloads" area. We've found this works well in WTP, another project that uses continuous builds. We haven't really decided a process yet for deciding when "we believe them suitable for adopter consumption" ... but, what ever that turns out to be, we'll be ready for it.
3. While we have so far resisted an update site for users, it seemed controversial enough not to remove what was already in place, (yet) and yes, if we ever do implement some version of it, another step will be added somewhere in the process to copy these "preliminary" versions the the "declared" area of an update site.
Let me know if I've missed anything.

Ultimately, as long as there's an obvious way to get from 'I want an orbit bundle' to 'I have an orbit bundle' then I'm not too concerned w/ internal structure. Given all the new Wiki docs I'm now seeing, I see great leaps in usability from the last time I looked at Orbit, 4 weeks ago. Kudos.
If I could pick one teeny little nit (after which I'll stop complaining, I promise!), I see that the whole of the Orbit website is Phoenix... except the downloads page: http://download.eclipse.org/tools/orbit/downloads/ ;-)

bug.short_desc: [Webapp] Ampersand in toc label shows as "&" on mac

long_desc.thetext:
See screenshot.
On windows it looks fine, it only seems to happen on the mac. Is the ampersand being escaped as "&" ? Perhaps some browsers handle the error and some don't.
Created an attachment (id=56305) screenshot
I may be overescaping the labels. I'll take a look at this one.
Targeting Eclipse 3.4
*** Bug 194457 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

This is not a Mac OS bug, it is a Safari bug. Using Firefox on Mac OS, the problem is not reproducible.
I confirmed that the TocFragmentServlet is generating the correct xml response to the ajax request. It is passing the "&" as "&" and safari is turning it into "&". Returning "&" in place of "&" has the same effect. Attempting to return an unescaped "&" caused all browsers to choke as this is not valid xml.
I tested this using the Safari 3 beta for Windows and the problem was not reproducible.
We will leave this issue as is for now and confirm that it's resolved by Safari once version 3 GAs.

bug.short_desc: [DnD] Dragging image file to editor should insert corresponding tag

long_desc.thetext: When dragging an image file from the navigator view to an active wst editor, it should insert the corresponding image tag for it: example: drag foo.jpg to the editor of bar.xhtml, should insert As this not needs to be the default behavior, we could implement a additional modifer key for that. Like Ctrl+DnD. Another thing could be implemented for the css editor where something like this could be inserted: url('path/to/image') To make this a little overkill, we could implement some new settings like templates. Let's say, we have a preferences page where you can assign a dnd-insert-template for specific file extensions: *.jpg -> *.html -> %FILECONTENT% *.css -> With this way, there could be done many quick inserts without having a full WYSIWYG functionality (which i personally don't like). Maybe there should also a project-wide setting for a base-directory from which the relative pathes to the files are calculated. Imagine a project structure like this: - pub (DocRoot) - images - css - templates This way, we need to set pub as base-dir when editing template files... I hope this is something interesting for other devs. I'm very open for comments. If there is enough interest, i would be happy to contribute such an extension.

bug.short_desc: [WorkbenchLauncher] Using ~ in the workspace selector dialog no longer refers to home directory

long_desc.thetext:
In Eclipse 3.2, I've been able to specify a workspace as local to my home directory by prefixing it with ~, so when starting, I have been able to select ~/Documents/SomeOtherWorkspace and it resolves to /Users/alex/Documents/SomeOtherWorkspace.
However, in Eclipse 3.3M4, if I type the same thing in, it gets resolved to /Path/To/Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/~/Documents/SomeOtherWorkspace, in other words, as a relative directory to the currently executing eclipse executable (which is located in the Contents/MacOS subdirectory).
If I start it with eclipse -data ~/Documents/SomeOtherWorkspace it seems to work as expected, and correctly resolves to the /Users/alex/Documents/SomeOtherWorkspace prefix. Is something being done to mangle the URL if it's not absolute or something? Has it changed recently if that's the case?
Is there special processing of the text field before being passed to the runtime?

I think this may be a VM issue. I just tried on 3.2.1 and I'm getting the same results. Stepping through the code, if I have a file created with the String "~/workspace", getAbsolutePath() returns "/Applications/Eclipse 3.3 I20061214-14XX/Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/~/workspace" I get this result whether or not I use 1.4.2 or 1.5. Can you confirm that there is a version combination where the desired behavior occurs?

Tilde expansion is a Unix shell feature, not a general feature in the OS filesystem calls or in java.io. Andre hacked tilde expansion in the Mac launcher (bug 33148), so perhaps something has gone wrong with that code. Andrew's launcher work is one possible culprit.
That was hacked into the launcher? Looking at the code path I dont see a way that the launcher could've made this work...
See the function expandShell in eclipseCarbon.c

That looks like it handles tilde expansion for command line arguments but this bug is about expanding them in the launcher dialog. According to the original text the -data expansion works but the expansion in the dialog does not. Looking at the code I'm not sure how it ever did.

Sorry, I was confused by comment #0 mentioning expansion when using the -data command line argument. I also don't know how this would have worked in the past, unless someone hacked it into the workspace selection dialog. I'll be quiet now.
I think we could replicate this behavior in the selection dialog. we have access to $user.home ...

It seems like a losing game to get into, in general. There are lots of places where file system paths are supplied by the user in the UI, and performing tilde expansion in only some of them would be inconsistent. I suspect we'd find all sorts of corner cases and inconsistencies trying to mimic this shell behaviour ourselves (consider ~username expansion, and the fact that tilde is a valid character in a unix path).
Alex, can you confirm that you believe tilde expansion was working at some point in the workspace selection dialog (as opposed to expansion of the -data command line argument)?

I was relatively sure that this worked in the past. But, if Kim was unable to replicate it on 3.2.1, I may have been wrong. (In which case, closing this as INVALID might be applicable.)
Note that it's not only the shell that does the expansion (but it does in this case) -- Finder.app allows you 'go to' folder ~ and other apps may also support it. I also think that if you use the ~ in the Info.plist (e.g. for the keyring) then it might be expected that the user be able to use ~ in the workspace selection dialog as well.
I've dropped this level to an 'enhancement' if it can be addressed. Whilst there's obviously workarounds, I don't believe that using workspaces buried inside the Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS is a sensible plan for Macs under any circumstances; an app is usually uninstalled by dragging the Eclipse.app into the trash, and if a user has unwittingly entered ~/Documents as the workspace when it launches, they'll trash their entire workspace too.
I agree with John's point that chasing the ~ will be found in potentially many places; but the workspace selection dialog is probably one of the more important ones.
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: [Theme] More Java editor features in Compare Editor

long_desc.thetext: When comparing java elements, the local side does not benefit from the fact that there is compilation context available. Specifically, there is no java search and no hyperlinking. Clearly this is tricky to do for the non-local part of the compare but for the local it should behave as an editor. Is this a problem with reusing the jdt editor part? (i.e. the compare can only provide a generic text editor)? This was initiated from compare of local vs. head.

We discussed this at the beginning of 3.3 and the general consensus was that embedding an editor part was not the right way to go because the editor or any of it's associated actions could operate on the assumption that the editor part was not wrapped by another editor part (i.e. the compare editor). A more acceptable approach would be to refactor the editor functionality so it could be used with any source viewer. The hope was that some of this work could be done in 3.3 but it never really got off the ground. Most of the work would need to be done at the JDT level.

On the general topic of embedding java editing, I know of two other cases where it was desired, one was in WID where we supported java snippet editing embedded in our properties pages (but I believe a partial solution was provided by JDT for this), and another came up recently in a UI Working Group call. I can get details of the latter if that's of use.
Clearly the current lack of java UI goodies in compare is frustrating, but I think there's perhaps an interesting trend of wanting to do "java editing types of things" in places that aren't the supplied JDT source editor.
Please see bug 46207.

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] Automatic split bar movement when one side is empty

long_desc.thetext: When a comparison yields an empty left or right hand side (e.g. class added or removed), it would be helpful if the split bar moved all (or most) of the way to the right or left so that you can see the entire source. Real estate for compares is always at a premium, so in the case where there is nothing to compare against, then being able to see all the source is helpful.
This shouldn't be too hard.
Fix released to HEAD
Verified using I20070206-0010

bug.short_desc: EPF adds "epf:version"s value to attribute "version"'s value if "version" is not set

long_desc.thetext: During load, persistency automatically sets the version attribute, say, of a content element to 1.0.0 ("epf:version"s value) if the versions value is not set. The auto added version value 1.0.0 may or may not get saved to xmi file dependent if the content element gets modified. This may be verified by adding a role to a lib with some main description but leaving its version as empty. Close the lib and load it again, the roles version is filled with value 1.0.0. Dont modify anything and close the lib, exam the roles xmi file: the version value 1.0.0 is not in the xmi file. Open the lib again and modify something in the main des for the role, and close the lib to exam the roles xmi file: the version value 1.0.0 is now in the file.
"epf:version" and "version" have the same local name. We need to overide XMLHandler's "getFeature" method so that passing "epf:version" would not return the feature for "version".
Looks like an EMF bug. will report it. For now we patch fix it in EPF to make it work for us. Fixed in MultiFileXMILoadImpl class.
Fix is verified on EPF1.2, build label:20070223-1817.

Can't auto added version value '1.2.0' when the value of version attribute is not set.
Steps: 1. Adding a role to a lib with some main description but leaving its version as empty. 2. Close the lib and load it again, check the roles version Result: The value of version attribute is empty
Question: Is a design?

The version in "epf:version" or "rmc:version" is not the same as the epf UMA meta model's attribute "version" for content description objects like role descriptions.
The epf UMA meta model's attribute "version" does not have a default value and should only be set by the user. Therefore, the current fixed behavour is as designed.
Close this bug as it is fixed in EPF 1.2 20070313-1700, and the behavior in comments #4 is work as designed.

bug.short_desc: Got 'Invalid thread access' error while upgrading a Library

long_desc.thetext: Reproduce Steps: 1. Download the Library from http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/downloads/v7_0/portfolio_mgmt/ 2. Unzip the downloaded package 3. Start EPF 1.1 and open the unzipped Library 4. Got an error message says 'Invalid thread access', upgrade failed.
This is a regression due to shell sharing code change. In this case, the upgarding thread becomes a non-UI thread after shell sharing code change.

The lib has many readonly files. The migration code was trying to open an error dialog to report this, but failed to do so because of thread violation. Fixed by excuting the dialog openning code in the UI thread.
Fixed, verified on build label 2007020702
Fix is verified on EPF 1.2 20070314. Both portfolio_mgmt, ITUP and RUP 7.0.1 are upgraded without error. Close it.
