bug.short_desc: Allow change to committer username

long_desc.thetext: An existing committer (rsuen) would like to change username to (rcjsuen). Some facility should be present to allow this.

(In reply to comment #0) > Some > facility should be present to allow this.
I'm not sure I understand why this is needed.

(In reply to comment #1) > (In reply to comment #0) > > Some > > facility should be present to allow this. > > I'm not sure I understand why this is needed.
In this case, Remy's current committer account (rsuen) is inconsistent with a number of other Eclipse-related accounts...e.g. IRC account, etc (rcjsuen). He would like them to be consistent.

If such a facility is created, it is probably in the best interests of everyone to enforce a limit on how often you can change it, I don't know, a couple of months or maybe once a year? *shrugs*
When I was first accepted as a committer I had told Wayne that I'd like my username to be rcjsuen. I'm guessing either a) he forgot it, or b) he ignored it because of the first initial/surname policy, or c) the webmaster chose to ignore it because of the policy.
There are of course cases where the policy is not used, but I'm guessing that might be the case because back then there was no policy?

I'd like to note that I was not aware that there was actually a policy in place when I noted it to Wayne. So if it can't be helped or the webmasters perceive this to be abused, we can just close this.

While I agree that a committer's ID is not always the one they would prefer, our IT policy is to follow the convention of first letter of given name + last name, up to 12 characters. Some of the old-school committers have IDs that don't meet this convention, but they were created before the Foundation's existence.
The purpose of this convention is to offer a faster response to the community; with over 800 committers sending us numerous requests for passwords, permissions, etc, it's easier for us to determine the committer ID with a fixed naming convention rather than having to do a lookup every time. From what I can tell, most applications that require you to supply an ID allow you to save the ID, hence not requesting it for each connection.
The Committer ID is also tied to many things: committer records, CVS commit history, IP trail, etc. so to change it is not trivial.
I'd like to recommend we close this as WONTFIX. Isn't the Eclipse Committer ID the coolest of them all?

Hi Denis,
Thanks for the reply.
(In reply to comment #5) > While I agree that a committer's ID is not always the one they would prefer, > our IT policy is to follow the convention of first letter of given name + last > name, up to 12 characters. Some of the old-school committers have IDs that > don't meet this convention, but they were created before the Foundation's > existence. > > The purpose of this convention is to offer a faster response to the community; > with over 800 committers sending us numerous requests for passwords, > permissions, etc, it's easier for us to determine the committer ID with a fixed > naming convention rather than having to do a lookup every time. From what I > can tell, most applications that require you to supply an ID allow you to save > the ID, hence not requesting it for each connection. > > The Committer ID is also tied to many things: committer records, CVS commit > history, IP trail, etc. so to change it is not trivial.
Yes, that's understood and appreciated. Do you think that some changing of IDs is doable with current staff without running you and others ragged? That is, would it be possible to do 5 a year, 10 a year or something on that order? Perhaps it could then be limited to a few 'extreme' cases a year (my guess is that it wouldn't be that many folks anyway).
> > I'd like to recommend we close this as WONTFIX. Isn't the Eclipse Committer ID > the coolest of them all? >
Indeed it is :)...at least to those of us Independents :).
Before closing this bug, could we get some idea from you/IT staff whether doing some of these would be possible? If so, how many would be reasonable? If staff were added to do this and/or other things reprioritized how would that change the situation (if at all)?
Thanksinadvance.

> Yes, that's understood and appreciated. Do you think that some changing of IDs > is doable with current staff without running you and others ragged?
Well, yes, it's not like changing a few IDs will automatically run us in the ground, but it does mean we'll be investing time in performing Name -> id lookups. It's not like we can afford to, as the community expects us to be responsive :)
There are two instances that I know of where a committer ID has changed:
- a committer's name had changed, so we changed the ID to match the new name. This was at the committer's request, it also maintained our naming convention, so this is absolutely warranted.
- a committer's ID, according to our standard, translated to an obscene word in the German language. As an example, Frank Uckerman's ID would be an obscenity that would certainly warrant a non-standard ID.
My only constraint to ID change requests is that they be requested only when necessary. It appears to me that Remy's ID change request is not stemmed from strict necessity, but rather convenience. We do appreciate this need for convenience, but, for the benefit of the community, a good naming convention is also convenient for Foundation IT :)
Scott, do we agree to disagree with Comment 7 and close this as "worksforme", or should we investigate further?

Hi Denis,
(In reply to comment #8) > Scott, do we agree to disagree with Comment 7 and close this as "worksforme", > or should we investigate further? >
I'd like to understand how much resources you would expect something like this to take, if, say 20 of such requests (necessity by your definition in #7) were to come in yearly. Any additional resources needed to address that mag of load?

Adding Bjorn and Ward to this for comment, and Sharon, as she maintains all the legal and paperwork when a committer's ID changes.
Another thing to consider is historical data, such as that on the Dash project: http://dash.eclipse.org/dash/commits/web-app/
One possible compromise would be to allow new committers to choose their ID before we provision their account.

(In reply to comment #11) > One possible compromise would be to allow new committers to choose their ID > before we provision their account.
Agreed. I thought this was already the case, but I haven't been provisioned recently.

Allowing a user to submit a requested ID, these forms would need to be changed:
NCRF: http://www.eclipse.org/legal/committer_process/committer_request.html
NPPR: http://www.eclipse.org/projects/project_provisioning_request.php
http://www.eclipse.org/legal/committer_process/individual_committer_questionnaire.php
http://www.eclipse.org/legal/committer_process/member_committer_questionnaire.php
I appreciate the accomodation expressed in Comment #4.

My suggestion is that we:
1) As per comment #11, we allow committers to choose/review their usernames when they are initially provisioned. 2) We convey to committers the need/reasons for care/stability in choice of username. 3) Only under extreme circumstances (as judged jointly by committer and EMO and using guidelines outlined in comment #5), the foundation goes through the changes described under comments #10 and #13.
If people don't agree with this approach, then please reopen bug.

bug.short_desc: PDE should disable adding jars to build path

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Read eclipse.platform newsgroup 2. Look for Re: getWorkspace() works ... when and where?, its just the latest in a series of similar discussions. 3.
More information: The basic problem is simple: the PDE uses the MANIFEST.MF to construct the classpath at run time and both the MANIFEST.MF and JDT's build path at compile time. This is fundamentally broken.

Created an attachment (id=56323) getWorkspace test plugin (based on hello world)
Same attachment as in the discussion group presenting the bug - the build path can be modified to the build path of the resource library.
The error is (quoting Jacek Pospychała): "I don't know why, but jvm doesn't throw any exception but jumps to nearest finally clause. And that is why you don't see any message."

PDE can't stop people from modifying a project's .classpath files or disable buttons on Java build path dialogs and wizards, nor should it. That's JDT tooling that we can't (and should not) interfere with.
Plus, I can think of several examples where manually adding JARs to the classpath is fine/necessary: - adding JARs that consitute the Bundle-Classpath header (eg. plug-ins that contain binary code and no source) - adding JARs that are needed to compile but not needed by the classloader at runtime (e.g. JARs needed by Ant tasks).
The fact that a plug-in's classpath is computed solely on contents of the manifest file is the first basic lesson of plug-in development and new plug-in developers should read the plug-in classpath documentation that ships with the SDK.

(In reply to comment #2) > PDE can't stop people from modifying a project's .classpath files or disable > buttons on Java build path dialogs and wizards, nor should it. > That's JDT tooling that we can't (and should not) interfere with.
Can't? "Won't" I understand, but surely disabling or warning is simple enough.
> > Plus, I can think of several examples where manually adding JARs to the > classpath is fine/necessary: > - adding JARs that consitute the Bundle-Classpath header (eg. plug-ins that > contain binary code and no source) > - adding JARs that are needed to compile but not needed by the classloader at > runtime (e.g. JARs needed by Ant tasks).
The PDE inability to support the full range of class path options through current plugin.xml UI is a shortcoming in its current implementation that should be fixed rather than used as an excuse.
The two minor examples you cite can be overcome by other means than the currently deceptive UI build path solution.
> > The fact that a plug-in's classpath is computed solely on contents of the > manifest file is the first basic lesson of plug-in development and new plug-in > developers should read the plug-in classpath documentation that ships with the > SDK.
Oh come on. The MANIFEST.MF is a relatively new invention whose characteristics are barely understood by the development team let alone us poor folks who have to use it. You may be an exception which is perhaps why you do not appreciate the problem many users face.
Furthermore in my experience your claim is not correct. Try searching for "classpath" in the PDE documentation. The first three entries are about Ant. None of the rest are truly about the classpath. Look through the table of contents. Any entry on classpath? Any page you recommend? Any page that you see recommended to people on the newsgroups?
Up against the poorly documented and complex MANIFEST.MF we have a tool from JDT that we have used many times and which prevents compile errors only to cause worse errors at run time. It's not good.

>Can't? "Won't" I understand, but surely disabling or warning is simple enough.
Can't. Said Java Build Path page is contributed by the jdt.ui plug-in and serves many generica and non-PDE purposes. If you can show me how to disable a button created and contributed by the jdt.ui plug-in from another plug-in (e.g the pde.ui plug-in), I will give you a shiny nickel :) It's not possible.
>Any page you recommend? Any page that you see recommended to people on the >newsgroups? http://help.eclipse.org/help32/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.pde.doc.user/guide/tools/editors/manifest_editor/dependencies.htm
Also refer to the Dependencies section in: http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-PDE-does-plugins/PDE-intro.html
The article dates back to 2003, so it pre-dates the usage of MANIFEST.MF, but the dependency concept remains exactly the same.
>Oh come on. The MANIFEST.MF is a relatively new invention whose >characteristics are barely understood by the development team let alone us >poor folks who have to use it.
The MANIFEST.MF may have been introduced in 3.0, but the concept of using a manifest file (manifest.mf or plugin.xml) to declare dependencies and set up the plugin classpath has been in Eclipse since before my time (ie. day 1).
No need for anyone to understand nor worry about the syntax of files. The user just does their his business on the Dependencies page of the manifest editor and saves. PDE takes care of the rest. simple enough for anybody - I hope.
>You may be an exception which is perhaps why you do not appreciate >the problem many users face. I am a sympathizer. But I am also a believer in reading documentation before posting problems on the newsgroups.
We have made a conscious effort to have the Plug-in Development Environment Guide, as it appears in 3.2 Help documentation, to cover as much breadth as possible. IMHO, we have done a good job on it and we plan to make it better for 3.3. If you have suggestions on how to improve it, please file enhancement requests in the pde/doc component.
*** Bug 195248 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I'm going to reopen this one.
Martin, do you think something is possible in this area, I think JDT UI would have to provide a hook to do something to that build path page. Or PDE would have to create a warning for users about adding external jars... I'm not sure what the right approach is but we need to something in this area imho.

This seems to be another one of those problems where it definitely needs some attention, but getting the right people to fix the right aspect of the problem may be problematic. Since I monitor the questions on most of Eclipse's newsgroup, I can assure you that this is one of the most common traps that newbies fall into and you find this problem turning up in many of the newsgroups, not just the newbies one. It would be a lot better to consider this problem as as a fundamental usability trap for folks new to Eclipse and find the right people to help fix the problem than to punt and say it can't be done. I'm a firm believer in the principle that where there's a will there's a way.

Chris/Ed, I agree that it is a common problem for newbies, and there is a will to fix the problem. However, everything I said in comment 4 is still valid. And my offer to pay up a shiny nickel for anyone who can provide a fix at the property page level still stands.
I suggest focusing on bug 176360 and bug 198465 would tell the user that something is wrong with their manually-tweaked classpath and provide quickfixes etc.
Cheap Torontonians! No wonder they city is going bankrupt! Here in Ottawa the going rate for patches of this magnitude is two-bits.

The original request for this bug is not feasible, I shouldn't of really reopened this issue, however, I couldn't find the other relevant bugs. There are other bugs open to help address issues with new users and how they treat the classpath:
See these: * bug 198465 * bug 198724 * bug 176360
The PDE team will look at getting fixes in for these in the M1/M2 timeframe. This should help new users significantly compared to what was available in the past.
It would have seemed better to have resolved this as a duplicate of the mostly closely related bugzilla which is probably https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=176360.

bug.short_desc: [terminal] There should be a way to remember terminal settings

long_desc.thetext: - set up a terminal connection - close the terminal ==> it would be great to remember the settings of previous terminal sessions

Each terminal view remembers the settings for its connection even when Eclipse Workbench is quit and re-started.
So, in order to keep (n) terminal connections, users need to open (n) terminal views, connect each with the terminal target desired and keep the views open. Views can be hidden (e.g. as fast views) but must not be closed in order to keep the connection settings.
Since this covers the most typical use cases, this bug is considered an enhancement request. Part of this request will be covered by integrating the Terminal with RSE. Then connection settings will be stored as RSE connections.
For clients who don't want to use RSE but use the plain Terminal View instead, a combobox with a history of previous connections would still be nice.

In some sense, a terminal connection is something like a launch configurations: - it starts something (a connection to a remote host) - the user may want to persist terminal connections - terminal connections might be shared
What do you think about using launch configurations to store terminal connections?
This would be optional. For a RCP based terminal, launch configurations would not be required.

I think that the terminal component should be very lightweight.
Connection sharing would be done by RSE at some point, or by the user application -- I've had numerous requests already by people who want to open terminal connections programmatically, so they would have the host info inside their application.
I'm not sure whether we'd want launch files just for the terminal. After all, there's not so many settings (just the host name and perhaps a port). I think that multiple users would typically login to different machines each. So I don't see very much value in sharing this, and I'd prefer a solution using Mementos or DialogSettings.

PS or what about a solution that always writes the settings into the metadata for now, and allowing to extend it in the future if required such that the settings can also be in the workspace?
I wouldn't do this with the 2.0 release however.

Michael, I noticed that with the recent ITerminalConnectorInfo changes, when I press the "Connect" or "New Terminal" button, I always get a connector selection dialog with an empty selection in the connector dropdown.
This is not user-friendly at all, and a regression, since previous versions always displayed the previous kind of connection with the previous settings. So if I typically always do SSH connections I can create them much more easily.
Could you restore the previous behavior?

long_desc.thetext: My plugin logs a successful status in the error log on completion of a task. It looks alright, has the green tick mark on the left. When I close the workbench and restart it, however, the green tick has changed to a resd cross for the existing messages.

When invoked, the code will add a log entry using an IStatus with a severity of OK. If the error log view is open the log will appear with a check mark icon. After shutting down and restarting the workbench the same log entry shows up with the error icon. Everything used in the attached plug-in is from eclipse.

bug.short_desc: A NullPointerException occured, when called RenderTask.render().

long_desc.thetext: Set a EmitterID on an instance of RenderTask. When ran the instance's render() method, a NullPointerException occured.

To fix this bug, engine: 1. add new APIs on IRenderOption - getEmitterID() - setEmitterID() 2.deprecate two APIs on RenderTask - getEmitterID() - setEmitterID()
caller should call new APIs to specify the emitter id, and engine will new a emitter instance when rendering a report.
